title: Will members of Sudan's military or paramilitary attempt to remove Omar al-Bashir as President of Sudan before 1 May 2017?
preds: Pundits have had to apologize for predicting this
The required mobilization before a coup attempt of this scale has not yet occurred, signaling that if one were to happen, it will not be in the next few months.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Sudan hasn't had a successful coup since 1989. While I assume a coup will happen eventually (Bashir doesn't seem like the kind of leader to enjoy a quiet reign) I'm not seeing the conditions for one anytime soon.

Signs of possible "brokered" transition, see link https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/sudan-appoints-prime-minister-for-first-time-since-1989/2017/03/02/02387b0e-ff4a-11e6-9b78-824ccab94435_story.html?_hsenc=p2ANqtz---_F-yw5-g-TD049YhlnMbGJ7uHoMhuRUd0662Wagthe7d8LLIBUSCYyGe9kj9bQ3mswiyviw3RqB1xNBMcve9Kpe9ig&_hsmi=43762671&utm_campaign=Daily%20Fringe%20&utm_content=43762671&utm_medium=email&utm_source=hs_email&utm_term=.c27c4753eb59
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Sudan Tribune reports a decision on removal of US sanctions on Sudan is due on July 8th.
The Obama administration eased sanctions in January.  Suspect a coup may be less likely before the July 8th date.

Cited resources provide a ~20% chance, so probability for 6 months must be much lower. A paramilitary attempt would be more likely, but a *quick* search with little personal knowledge in the matter reveals general but no specific indicators such as the Second Sudanese Civil War, allegations of corruption, genocide; indictment by the ICC; the president contends that the Sudanese military lent military support to Libyan rebels. They also lent support on the side of Saudi Arabia, and the US. in the Yemen intervention in 2015. It appears the worst foreign relations currently are with South Sudan, so any likely threat would likely originate there.
According to the general news and GJP consensus.

Hey, what if some generals--or for that matter sergeants--proposed a restructured polity in which he would become King?  That would be an attempt to remove him as President.

Another thought:  If some generals file a lawsuit or institute an impeachment proceeding or even just start up a petition to dump the guy, this would be a Yes, correct?  That would be an "attempt to remove," although not by a coup.  Granted this is improbable, but if we only had to guess about probable things it wouldn't be any more interesting than the hockey playoffs.

I see that good old Omar has recently been honored by the African Initiative for Pride and Dignity. That'll show those punks at the ICC, eh? http://allafrica.com/stories/201607290097.html
Al-Bashir merrily flits from country to country, oblivious to international calls for his arrest and, one presumes, completely secure at home. If he is to be removed, it will surely be for something that hasn't happened yet.

(no change) Not really the place to get the best exposure for this question, but just wonder how the various challenge scoring (to the extent that it matters) will work for questions that end in CY 2017?
Down 5% to be closer to consensus.
Dropping to 7% from 14% due to time and consensus.
Down 5% to be closer to consensus.

http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2016/06/bashir-declares-ceasefire-blue-nile-south-kordofan-160618042942706.html - Too early (?) to say how this ceasefire might affect al-Bashir's relationship with military. Reaffirming forecast.

Ordinarily a "coup" involves some level of organization and connivance, but "coup" is in the expansion, and only sort of implied there as if it might be the question's intent.  The actual question just asks about "members of Sudan's military..." trying to remove him.
Seems unlikely in the near future, will revise if a credible competitor comes into existence.

That's how they hold elections really and it's always possible. Western efforts to prop up stability present a potential for behind the scenes support that defies the definition of open source situational awareness. But there are probably some western military/intel entities defending him.
al-Bashir seems to have adequate Sudanese support to continue.  Leaving room for wildcards.
There are several similarly placed bozos in power in various countries.  He seems to be at no more risk than any of the others.
(no change) Just to stir the waters since not much is going on with this question. Wonder how it would be judged if he were to pass from this mortal coil in a traffic accident or a bathtub accident?
al-Bashir is popular in Sudan, the fact that Western countries would like him tried may give him additional popularity.

Cannot find any evidence and according to this link the financial situation appears strong and could help "win" military/paramilitary support for al-Bashir.
"Sudanâ€™s gold revenue has reached over 900 million dollars in the first quarter of this year, said the Minister of Minerals Ahmed Mohamed Sadiq al-Karouri on Tuesday"   http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article59153
Less time left for a military coup.
Passage of time, and Omar looks invincible. Probably not this year.

Information black hole. If there is an unsuccessful attempt, any details which emerge will need to be taken with a grain of salt. (cf. 2012 'coup attempt') If a coup is successful, we won't know anything about it until it's over. Hard to see any real threat to al-Bashir in this oppressive culture of fear, but risking 6% on "attempt" and possible fallout from Yemen campaign.

The statistical risk assessment at https://dartthrowingchimp.wordpress.com/2015/01/17/statistical-assessments-of-coup-risk-for-2015/ suggests a 14% annual chance of a coup in Sudan.  On the other hand, the "real risk" is probably a bit lower than that (maybe around 10%), because there don't seem to be any particular signs that a coup is imminent.  I'm going to start at 15%, to take advantage of the potential early closing of this question.

There has been some message traffic that al-Bashir has been trying to shore up outside support assets. One reason for that could be that he is hedging against a possible coup. At the moment, it is not certain that he has the complete loyalty of his military. This assessment may be updated in the future in the event further information is gleaned.

He has become closer to the Saudi govt recently and that will make him a target for the Iranians.  The involvement in Yemen can also lead to some discontent within his military.  I believe that plus the general economy in Sudan creates an environment with a better than 50/50 chance for his removal
al-Bashir probably will continue to rule the country as he has for many years
Africa is always changing leaders or in upheaval this situation will be no different. They never look to the common good only to power of the individual or tribe.

He's a pretty well entrenched dictator. Considering that he rode out the Arab Spring without so much a minor rebellion speaks volumes. Plus, everyone that hates him enough already left and is in South Sudan.
I find it unlikely that paramilitary groups in the Darfur, Blue Nile or South Kordofan would have the strength or geographical reach to attempt to remove al-Bashir.

Couldn't find anything suggesting evidence of an impending coup.   A couple of strange but interesting links:  1 - Chinese Ambassador talks about Chinese-Arab & Chinese-Sudan relations, & 2- a web page that looks like his removal is urgently desired (but not necessarily by Sudanese military or rebel group. 
1:  http://allafrica.com/stories/201605061219.html
2:  http://bashirwatch.org/
The graph is incredibly poor, but yes Omar has been indicted as a war criminal. He's claimed he will step down in 2020 again, but who can believe him at this point?
consensus seems about right. Long timescale, but Bashir's been there for quite some time, and hasn't had any serious internal competition.

Initial forecast until I can scan the DTC and Factbook. Hope to learn more about OaB's health, Sudan's economy especially related to climate change, and demographic (tribal) makeup. What I think I remember is that OaB is a typical strongman not particularly loved. —been winning friends for a long time too.
